metadata.title: Multiplexed measurement of variant abundance and activity reveals VKOR topology, 1 active site and human variant impact 2 3

body_text.text: warfarin response. Here, we used multiplexed, sequencing-based assays to measure the effects 23 of 2,695 VKOR missense variants on abundance and 697 variants on activity in cultured human 24 cells. The large-scale functional data, along with an evolutionary coupling analysis, supports a 25 four transmembrane domain topology, with variants in transmembrane domains exhibiting 26 strongly deleterious effects on abundance and activity. Functionally constrained regions of the 27 protein define the active site, and we find that, of four conserved cysteines putatively critical for 28 function, only three are absolutely required. Finally, 25% of human VKOR missense variants show 29 reduced abundance or activity, possibly conferring warfarin sensitivity or causing disease. 30

The enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR) drives the vitamin K cycle, which 32 activates blood coagulation factors. VKOR, an endoplasmic reticulum (ER) localized 33 transmembrane protein encoded by the gene VKORC1, reduces vitamin K quinone and vitamin 34 K epoxide to vitamin K hydroquinone (Li et al., 2004; Rost et al., 2004) . Vitamin K hydroquinone 35 is required to enable gamma-glutamyl carboxylase (GGCX) to carboxylate Gla domains on 36 Topology informs basic aspects of VKOR function including where vitamin K and warfarin 51 bind, so determining the correct topology and validating the homology model is critical. In 52 particular, VKOR has four functionally important, absolutely conserved cysteines at positions 43, 53 51, 132, and 135, the orientation of which differs between the two proposed topologies. In the 54 four transmembrane domain topology, all four cysteines are located on the ER lumenal side of 55 the enzyme. In this topology, cysteines 43 and 51 are hypothesized to be "loop cysteines" that 56 line, n = 2,695). The missense variant density is colored as a gradient between the lowest 10% 132 of abundance scores (blue), the WT abundance score (white) and abundance scores above WT 133 (red). d, Heatmap showing abundance scores for each substitution at every position within VKOR. 134

Heatmap color indicates abundance scores scaled as a gradient between the lowest 10% of 135 abundance scores (blue), the WT abundance score (white), and abundance scores above WT 136 (red). Grey bars indicate missing variants. Black dots indicate WT amino acids. e, Number of 137 substitutions scored at each position for abundance. f, Scatterplot comparing VAMP-seq derived 138 abundance scores to mean eGFP:mCherry (n = 1 replicate) ratios measured individually by flow 139 cytometry. Variants were selected at random to span the abundance score range. 140 We also measured VKOR variant activity, adapting a HEK293 cell assay based on vitamin 146 K-dependent gamma-glutamyl carboxylation of a cell-surface reporter protein (Haque et al., 147 2014) . In this assay, if VKOR is active, a Factor IX domain reporter is carboxylated, secreted and 148 retained on the cell surface where it is detected with a carboxylation-specific, fluorophore-labeled 149 antibody. However, if VKOR is inactive, the reporter is not carboxylated and the antibody cannot 150 bind (Fig. 2a) . We modified the HEK293 activity reporter cell line to eliminate endogenous VKOR 151 activity by knocking out both VKORC1 and its paralog, VKORC1-like 1 (VKORC1L1) ( Recombination of WT VKORC1 into the landing pad of the HEK293 VKOR activity reporter cell 155 line yielded robust reporter activation, demonstrating that the reporter line could be used to assess 156 the activity of a library of VKOR variants (Fig. 2b) . 157
We recombined a library of VKORC1 variants into the HEK293 activity reporter cell line, 158 and sorted recombinant cells into quartile bins based on carboxylation-specific antibody binding. 159

Each bin was deeply sequenced and, as for VAMP-seq, an activity score was computed for each 160 variant. Final activity scores and confidence intervals were computed from six replicates for a total 161 of 697 missense variants, 21.5% of those possible ( 2010). We found four clearly demarcated regions where charged substitutions profoundly reduced 187 VKOR abundance, relative to aliphatic substitutions (Fig. 3b) . To exclude the possibility that the 188 eGFP tag used in our VAMP-seq assay somehow affected topology, we also analyzed the activity 189 score data. The activity data, derived using native, untagged VKOR, revealed the same four 190 minima as the abundance data (Fig. 3c ). In addition to these four minima, we also observed an 191 activity score minimum at position 57, corresponding to a conserved serine at this position. This 192 serine occurs at the end of the lumenal half-helix hypothesized to shield the active site from non-193 specific oxidation, so it is likely this signal is the result of disruption of that half helix. Together, 194 these results strongly support the hypothesis that, like its distant bacterial homolog, human VKOR 195 has four transmembrane domains. 196

To validate these findings, we performed evolutionary coupling analysis to infer the three-197 dimensional structure suggested by co-evolution. We aligned 2,770 VKOR sequences from both 198 eukaryotes and prokaryotes and identified coupled residues using the EVcouplings software 199 We identified non-local evolutionary coupling patterns characteristic of three-dimensional 205 contacts, which also strongly supported the four transmembrane domain model. Using these 206 13 contacts, we computationally folded human VKOR, yielding a modeled structure similar to the 207 bacterial structure (RMSD = 2.58 ÅA over 97/143 Calpha, Figure 3 -figure supplement 1). The 208 predicted tertiary structure hasd a four-helix topology, with antiparallel contacts between 209 transmembrane domains 1 and 2 (Fig. 3e, Fig. 3f ) and between transmembrane domains 1 and 210 4 (Fig. 3e, Fig. 3g with columns showing median abundance score, median activity score, rescaled scores, and 377 specific activity score. 378

Variation in VKOR is linked to both disease and warfarin response, but the overwhelming 380 majority of VKOR variants found in humans so far have unknown effects. Thus, we curated a total 381 of 215 variants that had either been previously reported in the literature as affecting warfarin 382 response (Supplementary Table 3 Table 4 ). All synonymous variants with the exception of two were WT-like or 393 possibly WT-like, while the three nonsense variants scored had as having low abundance (Fig.  394 6a). Missense variants spanned all abundance categories, with 129 (60%) having WT-like or 395 possibly WT-like abundance. 30 missense variants were low abundance, and 12 were high 396 abundance. The single known pathogenic variant R98W was low abundance (Fig. 6b) . We also 397 classified 54 variants according to their activity (Supplementary Table 4 , but it is unclear whether these variants have appreciable effects 405 on abundance or activity. We found that warfarin resistance variants span a range of abundances 406 and that the distribution of warfarin resistant variant abundance was not different from missense 407 variants generally (Fig. 6c , two-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov test p= 0.438). Five warfarin-408 resistance variants had low abundance, suggesting that these variants must block drug binding 409 or increase activity to confer resistance. One variant, A26T, had high abundance, a possible 410 mechanism of warfarin resistance. The five warfarin resistance variants, R58G, W59L, V66M, 411 G71A, and N77S, whose activity we scored, were all WT-like. Thus, our abundance and activity 412 data are consistent with warfarin resistance arising largely from variants that block warfarin We conducted multiplexed assays to measure the effects of 2,695 VKOR variants on 425 abundance and 697 variants on activity. Both abundance and activity data provided evidence for 426 a four transmembrane topology, which was further supported by evolutionary couplings analysis. 427
body_text.section: Functional consequences of VKOR variants observed in humans 379

body_text.text: We evaluated a VKOR homology model in the context of the patterns of variant effects on 428 abundance we measured, and found that the homology model could explain these patterns. Low positions (V112, S113). In light of the fact that substitutions at F87 and Y88 resulted in low 435 abundance, we note that the modeled vitamin K binding mode would disrupt packing of VKOR 436 core residues and require repacking of helices to maintain protein stability (Merkle et al., 2018) . 437
body_text.section: Functional consequences of VKOR variants observed in humans 379

body_text.text: In addition to the active site, substitutions at the dilysine and, to a lesser extent, the diarginine ER 438 localization motifs caused abundance loss. 439
body_text.section: Functional consequences of VKOR variants observed in humans 379

body_text.text: We also used our large-scale functional data to analyze 215 VKOR variants found in 440 humans. 16% of these variants affect neither activity nor abundance; we identified 54 previously 441 uncharacterized low abundance or low activity variants that could be pathogenic or alter warfarin 442 response. We found that only one warfarin resistance variant had increased abundance, 443
body_text.section: Functional consequences of VKOR variants observed in humans 379

body_text.text: indicating that increased abundance is not a pervasive warfarin resistance mechanism. All five of 444 the warfarin resistance variants whose activity we scored were WT-like. Taken together these 445 data support the notion that warfarin resistance generally involves alterations to warfarin binding 446 rather than abundance or activity. We analyzed one known warfarin sensitivity variant, W5X, and 447 found that it is low abundance, suggesting that one should not exclude the possibility that any of 448 the 52 other low abundance variants, if found in a person, also confer warfarin sensitivity. 449 29 While our VKOR variant abundance and activity data illuminates various aspects of 450 VKOR's structure and function, the data have limitations. For example, neither assay captures 451 variant effects on mRNA splicing. Both assays have limited dynamic ranges, meaning that subtle 452 effects on abundance or activity cannot be discerned. In addition, both assays have inherent 453 noise, largely arising from the limited number of cells we can sample due to the bottleneck of cell 454 sorting. We account for this noise by filtering each dataset based on variant frequency and 455 presenting a confidence interval for each abundance and activity score. 456
body_text.section: Functional consequences of VKOR variants observed in humans 379

body_text.text: In the future, we envision that the assays we used could be employed to better understand 457 VKOR's interaction with warfarin. Here, we could measure warfarin's effect on both variant 458 abundance and activity, mapping the warfarin binding site more finely. In addition, we could 459 identify warfarin resistance mutations that have not yet been observed in the clinic and group 460 variants by their putative resistance mechanism. Overall, our work highlights the value of 461 scores scaled as a gradient between the lowest 10% of activity scores (blue), the WT activity 524 score (white) and activity scores above WT (red). Grey indicates missing data. b, Heatmap of 525 abundance scores for cysteines. Catalytic cysteines C132 and C135 labeled in green. Color 526 legend same as described in a, applied to abundance scores. 527 (Oldenburg et al., 2004) 26 A26T (Watzka et al., 2011) 26 A26P (Bodin et al., 2008) 27 L27V (Peoc'h et al., 2009) 28 H28Q (Watzka et al., 2011) 29 V29L (Oldenburg et al., 2004) 34 A34P (Harrington et al., 2011) 36 D36Y (Loebstein et al., 2007) 36 D36G (Watzka et al., 2011) 41 A41S (Rieder et al., 2005) 45 V45A (Oldenburg et al., 2004) 52 S52W 66 V66G (Watzka et al., 2011) 68 H68Y (Osman et al., 2006) 71 G71A (Watzka et al., 2011) 77 N77Y (Watzka et al., 2011) 77 N77S (Watzka et al., 2011) 123 I123N (Watzka et al., 2011) 128 L128R (Oldenburg et al., 2004) 139 Y139H

body_text.text: General reagents, DNA oligonucleotides, and plasmids. 560

Details on general reagents can be found in Supplementary Table 5. Unless otherwise  561 noted, all chemicals were obtained from Sigma and all enzymes were obtained from New 562 England Biolabs. E. coli were cultured at 37°C in Luria broth. All cell culture reagents were 563 purchased from ThermoFisher Scientific unless otherwise noted. HEK 293T cells (ATCC CRL-564 3216) and derivatives thereof were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium 565 supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 U ml -1 penicillin, and 0.1 mg ml -1 streptomycin. 566

Cells were induced with 2.5 ug mL -1 doxycycline. Cells were passaged by detachment with 567 trypsin-EDTA 0.25%, and cells were prepared for sorting by detachment with versene. All cell 568 lines tested negative for mycoplasma. Because our activity assay is vitamin-K dependent, all 569 activity assays were done with the same lot of FBS to ensure similar concentrations of vitamin K 570 in each replicate. 571
All synthetic oligonucleotides were obtained from IDT and can be found in 572
Supplementary

A gBLOCK with a codon-optimized sequence for human VKOR was ordered from IDT. It 577 was then cloned into the vector pHSG298 (Clontech). Saturation mutagenesis primers were 578 designed for each codon in VKOR from positions 2 to 163(Jain and Varadarajan, 2014) and 579 ordered resuspended from IDT. Forward and reverse primers for each position were mixed at 2.5 580 mM, and used in a PCR reaction with 125 pg of pHSG298-VKOR, 5% DMSO, and 5 uL of KAPA 581

Hifi Hotstart 2X ReadyMix. PCR products were visualized on a 0.7% agarose gel to confirm 582 amplification of the correct product. 583 584 49 PCR products were then quantified using the Quant-iT PicoGreen dsDNA Assay kit 585 (Invitrogen) using DNA control curves done in triplicate.

To pool, a total amount of DNA for 586 each reaction was calculated that maximized the volume to be drawn from the lowest 587 concentration PCR product. Pooled PCR products were cleaned and concentrated using 588

Zymogen Clean and Concentrate kit and then gel extracted. The pooled library was 589 phosphorylated with T4 PNK (NEB), incubated at 37°C for 30 minutes, 65°C for 20 minutes, and 590 then 4° indefinitely. 8.5 uL of this phosphorylated product was combined with 1 uL of 10X T4 591 ligase buffer (NEB) and 0.5 uL of T4 DNA ligase (NEB) to make a 10 uL overnight ligation reaction. 592
This reaction was incubated at 16°C overnight. 593

The overnight ligation was then cleaned and concentrated (Zymogen) and eluted in 6 uL 594 of ddH2O. 1 uL of this ligation was then transformed into high efficiency E. coli using 595 electroporation at 2 kV. Each reaction contained 1 uL of ligation (or ligation control or pUC19 10 596 pg/uL) and 25 uL of E. coli. 975 uL of pre-warmed SOC media was added to each cuvette after 597 electroporation, transferred to a culture tube, and recovered at 37°C, shaking for 1 hour. At 1 598 hour, 1 and 10 uL samples from all cultures were taken and plated on appropriate media (LB + 599 kanamycin for ligation and ligation control; LB + ampicillin for pUC19), the remaining 989 uL was 600 used to inoculate a 50 mL culture (+ kanamycin). Plates and 50 mL culture were incubated at 601 37°C overnight (shaking for 50 mL culture). Colonies on plates were then counted, and counts 602 were used to calculate how many unique molecules were transformed to gauge coverage of the 603 library. 50 mL culture was spun down and midiprepped. 604

To transfer the library from pKan to the recombination vector, the pKan library and 605 recombination vector were digested with XbaI and AflII for 1 hour at 65°C. The library and cut 606 vector were then gel extracted. The library was then ligated with the cut vector at 5:1 using T4 607 ligase, overnight at 16°C. The ligation was heat inactivated the next morning, clean and 608 concentrated. Another high efficiency transformation was performed the same as described 609 above, except this ligation was plated on LB + ampicillin (antibiotic switching strategy). Plates and 610 50 50 mL culture were incubated at 37°C overnight (shaking for 50 mL culture). Colonies on plates 611 were then counted, and counts were used to calculate how many unique molecules had been 612 transformed to gauge coverage of the library. A 50 mL culture was spun down and midiprepped. 613
To barcode individual variants, plasmid library harvested from midiprep was digested with 614

EcoRI-HF and NdeI at 37°C for 1 hour, 65°C for 20 minutes. Barcode oligos were ordered from 615 IDT, resuspended at 100 uM, and then annealed by combining 1 uL each of primer with 4 uL 616 CutSmart Buffer and 34 uL ddH2O and running at 98°C for 3 minutes followed by ramping down 617 to 25°C at -0.1°C/second. After annealing, 0.8 uL of Klenow polymerase (exonuclease negative, 618 NEB) and 1.35 uL of 1 mM dNTPS was then combined with the 40 uL of product to fill in the 619 barcode oligo (cycling conditions: 25°C for 15:00, 70°C for 20:00, ramp down to 37°C at -0.1°C/s). 620
Digested vector and barcode oligo were then ligated overnight at 16°C. 621
The overnight ligation was then cleaned and concentrated and eluted in 6 uL of ddH2O. 1 622 uL of this ligation was then transformed into high efficiency E. coli using electroporation at 2 kV. 623

Each reaction contained 1 uL of ligation (or ligation control or pUC19 10 pg/uL) and 25 uL of E. 624 coli. 975 uL of pre-warmed SOC media was added to each cuvette after electroporation, 625 transferred to a culture tube, and recovered at 37°C, shaking for 1 hour. At 1 hour, 1 and 10 uL 626 samples from water and pUC19 cultures were taken and plated on LB supplemented with 627 ampicillin. For ligation and ligation control, four flasks were prepared with 50 mLs of LB and 628 ampicillin, and then 500 uL, 250 uL, 125 uL, 62.5 uL was sample from the 1 mL of recovery and 629 transferred into a corresponding flask. From those flasks, 1 uL, 10 uL, and 100 uL, were sampled 630 and plated onto LB ampicillin plates. Plates and 50 mL culture were incubated at 37°C overnight. 631

Colonies on plates were then counted, and counts were used to calculate how many unique 632 molecules were transformed to gauge number of barcodes. Flask with the target number of 633 barcodes was then spun down and midiprepped. 634 635 Cell line description 636

FIGREF0.text: vitamin K-dependent blood clotting factors. VKOR is inhibited by the anticoagulant drug warfarin 37 (Czogalla et al., 2016; Zimmermann and Matschiner, 1974), and VKORC1 polymorphisms 38 contribute to an estimated ~25% of warfarin dosing variability (Owen et al., 2010). For example, 39 variation in VKORC1 noncoding and coding sequence can cause warfarin resistance (weekly 40 warfarin dose > 105 mg) or warfarin sensitivity (weekly warfarin dose < ~10 mg) (Osinbowale et 41 al., 2009; Yuan et al., 2005). 42 Though 15 million prescriptions are written for warfarin each year 43 (https://www.clincalc.com), fundamental questions remain regarding its target, VKOR. For 44 example, the structure of human VKOR is unsolved, though a bacterial homolog has been 45 crystallized (Li et al., 2010). A homology model based on bacterial VKOR has four transmembrane 46 domains, but the quality of the homology model is unclear, as human VKOR has only 12% 47 sequence identity to bacterial VKOR. Moreover, experimental validation of VKOR topology 48 yielded mixed results: similar biochemical assays suggested either three-or four-49 transmembrane-domain topologies (Schulman et al., 2010; Tie et al., 2012; Wu et al., 2018). 50

However, a destabilized variant is degraded by 125 protein quality control machinery, leading to low eGFP fluorescence. b, Flow cytometry is used to 126 bin cells based on their eGFP:mCherry fluorescence intensity. FIGREF6.text: Hopf et al., 2012; Marks et al., 2011). Local patterns of evolutionary couplings (i.e. between 200 nearby positions, i to i+4) supported a four-helix topology. The helices predicted by these local 201 evolutionary couplings overlapped 70 of the 82 residues in alpha-helices of the bacterial structure 202 (PDB 4NV5) (Shen et al., 2017) and included in our alignment, non-gapped in >70% of aligned 203 VKOR sequences (hyper-geometric test p-value = 3.26 -23 , Fig. 3d). 204

FIGREF7.text: ), which are only possible in a four-helix topology. 211 Comparison of our abundance data to the energy required to insert different amino acids 212 into the membrane yields additional evidence for the four transmembrane domain model. The 213 apparent change in free energy (ΔΔGapp) of insertion relative to wild type for every amino acid has 214 been determined experimentally using deep mutational scanning of bacterial membrane proteins 215 (A. A. Elazar et al., 2016). Median abundance score and ΔΔGapp for each amino acid are 216 correlated (Fig. 3h). In particular, the large energetic cost of insertion of transmembrane domains 217 with charged amino acids is apparent, including within the second transmembrane domain TMD2. 218 Beyond insertion energies of individual amino acids, the overall hydrophobicity of transmembrane 219 helices contributes to membrane protein insertion (A. A. Elazar et al., 2016), as well as topology 220 (A. Elazar et al., 2016) and degradation (Guerriero et al., 2017). To determine whether overall 221 helix hydrophobicity was a large factor contributing to abundance scores, we calculated the free 222 energy for insertion (ΔGhelix) of each helix in the four transmembrane domain model using the ΔG 223 prediction server v1.0 (Hessa et al., 2007). The four helices of VKOR have different ΔGhelix, with 224 only transmembrane domain 3 having favorable ΔGhelix for insertion (TMD1: 0.435, TMD2: 1.551, 225 TMD3: -1.749, and TMD4: 1.734). Interestingly, we observed that TMD3 has a high density of 226 substitutions with WT-like scores (Figure 3-figure supplement 2), suggesting that TMD3'Abundance, activity, and evolutionary data support four transmembrane 230 domains. a, Three and four transmembrane domain (TMD) models of VKOR, with TMDs in dark 231 grey (Li et al., 2010; Tie et al., 2012). b, Windowed abundance score means (width = 10 positions) 232 for charged substitutions (green) and aliphatic substitutions (gold). Dark grey boxes correspond 233 to TMDs proposed in the four domain model. Dashed lines show median synonymous and the 234 nonsense abundance scores. c, Windowed activity score means (width = 10 positions) for 235 charged substitutions (green) and aliphatic substitutions (gold). Boxes and dashed lines as 236 described in b. d, Secondary structure classification from local evolutionary couplings shown as 237 alpha scores calculated for alpha helices (red) and beta sheets (blue). Dashed lines show 238 significance cut-offs for alpha helices (1.5, red) and beta sheets (0.75, blue) (Toth-Petroczy et al., 239 2016). e, A contact map derived from evolutionary couplings. Black points show pairs of positions 240 with significant coupling. Light green points show predicted contacts between TMD1 and TMD2. 241 Dark green points show predicted contacts between TMD1 and TMD4. f, Predicted tertiary 242 15 contacts between TMD1-TMD2 (shown in light green in e) and g, TMD1-TMD4 (shown in dark 243 green in e) shown on the evolutionary couplings-derived hVKOR structural model. h, Scatterplot 244 comparing change in free energy for membrane insertion (A. A. Elazar et al., 2016) (∆∆Gapp) to 245 median abundance score for each amino acid substitution. Cytoplasmic and lumenal positions 246 shown in black, TMD2 in light green, and TMDs 1, 3, and 4 in dark green. Charged substitutions 247 shown as circles, all other substitutions as triangles. 248

FIGREF10.text: source data 3. Insertion energies from Elazar et al., 2016. Amino acids with 253 calculated insertion energy. 254Detailed structural context of VKOR variant abundance effects 255Having confirmed that human VKOR has four transmembrane domains, we next explored 256 the detailed pattern of mutational effects we observed in the context of a four transmembrane 257 domain homology model. We generated a homology model of human VKOR with I-TASSER using 258 the bacterial VKOR structure(Shen et al., 2017;Yang et al., 2015). We performed hierarchical 259 clustering of positions based on abundance scores, which yielded four groups of positions with 260 characteristic mutational patterns(Fig. 4a). In Group 1, most substitutions were neutral or 261 increased abundance; in Group 2, charged amino acid and proline substitutions decreased 262 abundance; in Group 3, all substitutions decreased abundance; and in Group 4, all substitutions 263 decreased abundance profoundly. Each group corresponded to a spatially distinct region of the 264 homology model structure(Fig. 4b).265 Group 1 positions were located in or adjacent to cytoplasmic and ER lumenal loops, which 266 were more tolerant of substitutions than the transmembrane domains. At four Group 1 positions, 267 K30, R33, R35, and R37, almost every substitution increased abundance. These positively 268 charged positions are positioned either at the edge of TMD1 (K30) or in the ER lumen directly 269 abutting the top of TMD1 (R33, R35, and R37). The "positive inside rule" (von Heijne, 1989), 270 suggests that positive charges in membrane proteins generally reside in the cytoplasm, and this 271 phenomenon is important for driving topology and membrane insertion (A. Elazar et al., 2016; 272 Nilsson and von Heijne, 1990; von Heijne, 1989). K30, R33, R35, and R37 violate the positive 273 inside rule, and substitutions at these positions may increase abundance by reducing charge 274 inside the ER, reducing topological frustration or increasing membrane insertion efficiency. 275 Compared to the other 12 arginine and lysine positions in WT VKOR, K30, R33, R35, and R37 276 are the only ones where substitutions generally increased abundance (Figure 4-figure 277 supplement 1). Our observations are consistent with a screen of rat VKOR variants intended to 278 improve protein expression in E. coli where deletion of positions 31 to 33 increased protein levels 279 (Hatahet et al., 2015). 280 In Group 2, charged amino acids or proline substitutions generally decreased abundance. 281 Group 2 consisted mostly of transmembrane positions that had side chains projecting into the 282 lipid bilayer. Such transmembrane positions usually have hydrophobic, nonpolar side chains 283 (Ulmschneider and Sansom, 2001). Proline has poor helix forming propensity, explaining why 284 proline substitutions decreased abundance at these positions. Group 3 consisted of a mixture of 285 cytoplasmic, ER lumenal and transmembrane positions where most substitutions decreased 286 abundance. The cytoplasmic positions in this group included the putative dilysine ER localization 287 motif at positions 159 and 161. Also in this group were R98, part of another putative ER retention 288 motif at positions 98 and 100, and a glycine adjacent to TMD1 at position nine. The 289 transmembrane positions had side chains projecting towards neighboring transmembrane 290 helices, suggesting that, as for other membrane proteins (Fleming and Engelman, 2001; Mravic 291 et al., 2019), intramolecular sidechain packing is important for abundance. 292 Finally, substitutions in Group 4, consisting of positions G19, Y88, I141, and L145, resulted 293 in catastrophic loss of abundance. These positions are all in transmembrane domains with side 294 chains projecting into the interior of the protein. On the basis of strict mutational intolerance of 295 these positions, we hypothesized that their coordinated side chain packing comprises the core of 296 the VKOR four helix bundle. Indeed, Group 4 residues had dramatically lower relative solvent 297 accessibility than Groups 1-3 (Fig. 4c). 298 The four transmembrane domain homology models also allowed us to explain VKOR's 299 unusual trimodal distribution of variant abundance scores. Previous VAMP-seq derived 300 abundance score distributions for the cytosolic proteins TPMT and PTEN were bimodal (Figure 301 4-figure supplement 2) (Matreyek et al., 2018), and 15 of 16 deep mutational scans of other 302 soluble proteins using a variety of other assays also exhibited bimodal functional score 303 distributions (Gray et al., 2017). Because VKOR is an ER resident, transmembrane protein, we 304 hypothesized that its unusual trimodal abundance score distribution resulted from transmembrane 305 domain substitutions. Indeed, the lowest mode of the distribution was composed almost Hierarchical clustering of abundance scores and distributions of abundance and 312 activity scores by domain. a, A heatmap showing hierarchical clustering of positions based on 313 abundance score vectors, with the dendrogram above. Groups of positions, chosen based on the 314 dendrogram, are numbered and colored. Heatmap color indicates abundance scores scaled as a 315 gradient between the lowest 10% of abundance scores (blue), the WT abundance score (white) 316 20 and abundance scores above WT (red). Grey bars indicate missing variants. Black dots indicate 317 WT amino acids. b, Positions in groups 1-4 shown on the VKOR homology model, with numbers 318 and colors corresponding to panel a. c, Boxplot showing relative solvent accessibility of positions 319 in each cluster determined using DSSP (Kabsch and Sander, 1983; Touw et al., 2015) and 320 colored as in b. Bold black line shows median, box shows 25th and 75th percentile. Line shows 321 1.5 interquartile range above and below percentiles, and outliers are shown as black points. d, 322 Histograms of abundance scores for missense variants in the cytoplasmic, ER lumenal, or 323 transmembrane domains. e, Histograms of activity scores for missense variants in the 324 cytoplasmic, ER lumenal, or transmembrane domains. 325Variant activity and abundance identify functionally constrained regions of VKOR 326We reasoned that our activity and abundance data could reveal the location of functionally 327 important positions in VKOR, including the active site, since functionally important positions 328 should have many loss-of-activity but few loss-of-abundance variants. Thus, we calculated the 329 specific activity for each variant by taking the ratio of its rescaled activity score and abundance 330 scores (see Methods) ratio. We computed the median specific activity for each position; 331 substitutions at positions with low median specific activity generally have low activity relative to 332 their abundance. We set a specific activity threshold based on two absolutely conserved cysteines 333 that form VKOR's redox center, C132 and C135. Using this threshold, positions with the lowest 334 12.5% of specific activity scores and with at least four variants scored for activity were deemed 335 functionally constrained and mapped on the homology model of VKOR(Fig. 5a, Figure 5-figure 336supplement 1). These 11 functionally constrained positions are organized around C132 and C135 337 and define, at least in part, the VKOR active site(Fig. 5b,c, Figure 5-figure supplements 1).338 Among the functionally constrained positions are six positions previously identified in vitamin K 339 docking simulations (Czogalla et al., 2016) (Figure 5-figure supplement 1), including F55, which 340 is hypothesized to bind vitamin K. Three functionally constrained positions, G60, R61, and A121, 341 did not match any position in the active site predicted by docking, but were immediate neighbors 342 of W59 and L120, positions that were. 343 Besides C132 and C135, VKOR has two additional absolutely conserved cysteines, C43 344 and C51. In the four transmembrane domain model, C43 and C51 are postulated to be loop 345 cysteines that relay electrons to the C132/C135 redox center (Liu et al., 2014). We classified C43 346 as having low specific activity, but we only observed one variant at this position, so it was not 347 included in our set of functionally constrained positions (Figure 5-figure supplement 2). In 348 contrast, substitutions at C51 resulted in only modest activity loss, a phenomenon that has been 349 observed previously (Shen et al., 2017). Interestingly, every substitution at C51 and 15 of 19 at 350 C132 decreased VKOR abundance (Figure 5-figure supplement 2). Inside cells, the majority of 351 22 VKOR molecules have a C51-C132 disulfide bond, and warfarin binds to this redox state of VKOR 352 (Shen et al., 2017). Since disruption of this disulfide bond apparently impacts abundance as well 353 as activity, this bond may be important for VKOR folding and stability. 354 VKOR is thought to contain two sequences important for ER localization. The first is a 355 diarginine motif (RxR) at positions 98-100, and the second is a dilysine motif (KXKXX) at positions 356 159-163. While we did not directly measure localization, we found that only six of 19 R98 variants 357 and seven of 14 R100 variants resulted in low abundance (Figure 5-figure supplement 3). In 358 contrast, nearly all variants at K159 (14 of 18) and K161 (17 of 19) resulted in low abundance 359 (Figure 5-figure supplement 3). A histidine substitution was tolerated at position 161, which 360 mimics the KXHXX motif commonly found in coronaviruses and a small number of human proteins 361 (Ma and Goldberg, 2013). Because protein localization and degradation are coupled (Hessa et 362 al., 2011), we suggest that the reductions in abundance we observe are the result of degradation 363 caused by mislocalization, and that the dilysine motif at positions 159-163 is essential for VKOR 364 ER localization. Overall, comparison of VKOR variant activity and abundance revealed 365 functionally important regions, refining our understanding of the active site, redoxFunctionally constrained positions reveal VKOR active site and critical cysteines. 369 a, Positions with the lowest 12.5% of median specific activity scores and at least four variants 370 scored for activity are shown as magenta spheres on the VKOR homology model. Cysteines 371 C132, and C135, also in the bottom 12.5% of median specific activity scores, are shown in green 372 spheres. b, Magnified view of the redox center cysteines (positions 132, and 135, green spheres) 373 and surrounding residues that define the active site (magenta spheres). Residues shown in 374 transparent spheres, with side chains also shown in sticks. c, panel b rotated 120°C. 375

Because 183 charged amino acids occur infrequently in transmembrane domains and should be less tolerated, 184 we reasoned we could discriminate between these two models using a sliding window average of 185 the effect of charged substitutions on VKOR abundance (A. back_matter.text: HEK293T cells with a serine integrase landing pad integrated at the AAVS1 locus were 638 used (Matreyek et al., 2017) . Disruption of VKORC1 and VKORC1L1 was confirmed by performing nested PCR, TA cloning, 653 and then sequencing of products. We detected three alleles for both VKORC1 and VKORC1L1, 654indicating that these loci are triploid in HEK293 cells. 655A Western blot was also used to confirm absence of VKOR protein product in our activity 656 reporter cell line. Protein lysates were harvested from ~1 million cells using 100 uL NP40 lysis 657 buffer with freshly prepared protease inhibitor cocktail and 1 mM PMSF. Protein lysates were 658Qubited for concentration, and 20 ug of each protein lysate was loaded. 4-12% BisTris NuPage 659 gel (Thermo Fisher) was used with MES buffer + 500µl of antioxidant added to the inner chamber. 660The gel ran at 150V for 90 min. Gel was then transferred to Nitrocellulose using 1X transfer buffer 661 20% EtOH at 24V for 1 hour on ice. The blot was washed for 5 minutes with 1X TBS-T 0.1% 662 52 Tween 3 times. Blot was then blocked for overnight 1X TBS-T 0.1% Tween + 5% Milk. Blot was 663 then washed for 5 minutes with 1X TBS-T 0.1% Tween 3 times. Blot was then cut in half at the 664 between the 25kDa and 35kDa molecular weight markers. The bottom blot was incubated with: 665 αVKOR 1:1000 + 1X TBS-T 0.1% Tween + 5% Milk. The top blot was incubated with αbeta-actin 666 dHRP 1:1000+ 1X TBS-T 0.1% Tween + 5% Milk. Both blots were incubated with their primary 667 antibodies overnight at 4ºC. The αVKOR blot was washed for 5 minutes with 1X TBS-T 0.1% 668 Tween 3 times. The αVKOR blot was then incubated with 1:10,000 secondary anti-mouse-HRP 669 (GE Healthcare NA931V) + 1X TBS-T 0.1% Tween + 5% Milk for one hour. The αbeta-actin dHRP 670 blot remained in primary antibody during this time, as no secondary antibody is needed for a direct 671 HRP conjugate. Both blots were then washed for 5 minutes with 1X TBS-T 0.1% Tween 3 times. 672Blots were then incubated with Supersignal West Dura Extended Duration Substrate (Thermo 673 Fisher). 500µl of both substrates incubated on blot for 5 min. Blots were then dried by kimwipe 674 and exposed using the colorimetric and chemiluminescence functions on the BioRad ChemiDoc 675 MP (Biorad). Recombined cells were run on a BD Aria III FACS machine. Cells were prepared for 711 sorting as described above, and were then gated for live, recombined singlets. A ratio of 712 eGFP/mCherry was created using the BD Diva software as a unique parameter, and the 713 histogram of this ratio was divided into four equal bins. Each quartile was sorted into a 5 mL tube 714 54 on "4-Way Purity" mode. Sorted cells were grown out for 2-4 days post sorting to ensure enough 715 DNA for sequencing. The details of replicate sorts for activity assay are in Supplementary Table  716 1. 717 718

Factor IX Gla domain antibody specific for carboxylation was conjugated to APC following 720 that low frequency variants introduced noise to the analysis. These frequencies were then each 791 57 weighted by multiplying by 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1 in a bin-wise fashion. We generated a replicate 792 score for each variant by using min-max normalization: normalizing to the median weighted 793 average of the nonsense distribution set at 0 and the median weighted average of the 794 synonymous distribution set at 1. We then averaged those scores for a final, experiment-wide 795 variant score. Standard deviation and standard error were also calculated for each variant, and 796 95% confidence intervals were estimated using standard error, assuming a normal distribution. 797Abundance and activity classifications were assigned by assessing variant score and confidence 798 intervals in relation to synonymous variant distribution. To do this, we established a cut-off that 799 separated the 5% of synonymous variants with the lowest abundance (or activity) scores from the 800 95% of synonymous variants with higher abundance (or activity) scores. Variants with both scores 801 and upper confidence intervals below this threshold were classified as "low," while those with 802 scores below but upper confidence above were classified as "possibly low." Variants with scores 803 and lower confidence intervals above the threshold were classified as "WT-like", while those with 804 scores above lower confidence intervals below the threshold were classified as "possibly WT-805 like." Finally, another threshold was set that separated the 5% of synonymous variants with the 806 highest scores from the rest of the synonymous distribution. Variants that had scores above this 807 threshold, with lower confidence intervals above the lower threshold were classified as "high. EVcouplings extracts the constraints between pairs of residues, as evidenced in 816 alignments of homologous sequences: first homologous sequences must be collected and 817 58 aligned, and then a model of statistical energy costs and benefits between residues is fit to explain 818 the sequence variation in the alignment. We collected an alignment of 2770 sequences using 819 jackhammer (http://hmmer.org/) to query the human VKOR sequence against UniRef100 820 (https://www.uniprot.org/uniref/), with a bitscore per residue cutoffs of 0.4 and 7 search iterations. 821We predicted secondary structures where the summed strength of couplings at would-be alpha 822 helix and beta strand contacts scored above 1.5 for alpha helices and 0.75 respectively, for two 823 or more consecutive residues. We extended the called helices and strands by one residue on 824 each side for a minimum structure size of four residues. All methods used for building alignments, Activity and abundance scores were rescaled so that the lowest score present in the 840 dataset was set at 0, and the highest score at 1. A ratio of rescaled activity to rescaled abundance 841 (specific activity) was then calculated for every variant. Using variant specific activity scores, 842 median specific activity was calculated for each position. Threshold for classification as an active 843 59 site position was drawn based on scores of known redox cysteines at positions 132 and 135, 844 resulting in lowest 12.5% of median specific activity scores being classified as active site residues. 845We additionally required that any position within this group had been scored for at least four 846 variants to eliminate noise from poor sampling.
